alert.note: Alert for Saint Croix; Saint John; Saint Thomas (Virgin Islands) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS San Juan (San Juan, Puerto Rico)
info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued November 18 at 3:00PM AST by NWS San Juan
info.description: ...WIDESPREAD FLOODING NO LONGER EXPECTED... ...LOCALLY HEAVY RAIN MORE LIKELY MONDAY OR TUESDAY... The energy from Potential Tropical Cyclone 22 was absorbed by an old shearline and shunted to the north northeast. A long line of showers and heavy thunderstorms now exists north northeast to south southwest across the Dominican Republic and will move toward the area only very slowly--possibly not arriving until a cold front from the north moves into the local area on Monday or Tuesday. Heavy rains may still fall over the Mona Channel and northwest Puerto Rico before Tuesday, but this is much less certain. Based on latest guidance, a 5-day rainfall totals may still be between 2 and 4 inches with isolated higher amounts, but will be focused more on the north side of the island, and over the local mountains late Monday through Tuesday night, since wind flow will shift to being from the north. Elsewhere, including the U.S. Virgin Islands the potential exists for rainfall totals to reach 1 to 2 inches. Therefore, there is a risk for ponding of water, flooding of urban areas, roads and small streams. Isolated life threatening flash flooding and mudslides are possible as well, but these are likely to be delayed until late Monday or Tuesday. Since widespread flooding is not expected at this time, a Flash Flood Watch is not expected to be invoked over the weekend. This product will be updated if conditions change.

area.areaDesc: Saint Croix; Saint John; Saint Thomas
